official-title.#text: To authorize the Administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency to establish a program of awarding grants to owners or operators of water systems to increase resiliency or adaptability of the systems to any ongoing or forecasted changes to the hydrologic conditions of a region of the United States.

sponsor.#tail: introduced the following bill; which was referred to the

committee-name.#tail: , and in addition to the Committees on
, for a period to be subsequently determined by the Speaker, in each case for consideration of such provisions as fall within the jurisdiction of the committee concerned

short-title.#text: Water Infrastructure Resiliency and Sustainability Act of 2013

text.#text: This Act may be cited as the
In this section:

term.#tail: means the Administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency.

text.#text: The term

term.#tail: means the quality, quantity, or reliability of the water resources of a region of the United States.

text.#text: The term

term.#tail: means an entity (including a regional, State, Tribal, local, municipal, or private entity) that owns or operates a water system.
term.#text: owner or operator of a water system

text.#text: The term
a non-Federal entity that has operational responsibilities for a federally, tribally, or State-owned water system; and
an entity established by an agreement between—
an entity that owns or operates a water system; and
at least one other entity.

term.#text: owner or operator of a water system

text.#text: The term

header.#text: Owner or operator of a water system

text.#text: The term
a community water system (as defined in

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text: section 1401 of the Safe Drinking Water Act

text.#text: a treatment works (as defined in

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: ), including a municipal separate storm sewer system (as such term is used in the

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text: section 212 of the Federal Water Pollution Control Act

text.#text: a decentralized wastewater treatment system for domestic sewage;
a groundwater storage and replenishment system;
a system for transport and delivery of water for irrigation or conservation; or
a natural or engineered system that manages floodwaters.

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: shall establish and implement a program, to be known as the Water Infrastructure Resiliency and Sustainability Program, under which the

awards grants in each of fiscal years 2014 through 2018 to owners or operators of water systems for the purpose of increasing the resiliency or adaptability of the systems to any ongoing or forecasted changes (based on the best available research and data) to the hydrologic conditions of a region of the United States.

text.#text: The

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Water Infrastructure Resiliency and Sustainability Act of 2013/s:2/ss:b

text.#text: As a condition on receipt of a grant under this section, an owner or operator of a water system shall agree to use the grant funds exclusively to assist in the planning, design, construction, implementation, operation, or maintenance of a program or project that meets the purpose described in
conserving water or enhancing water use efficiency, including through the use of water metering and electronic sensing and control systems to measure the effectiveness of a water efficiency program;
modifying or relocating existing water system infrastructure made or projected to be significantly impaired by changing hydrologic conditions;
preserving or improving water quality, including through measures to manage, reduce, treat, or reuse municipal stormwater, wastewater, or drinking water;
investigating, designing, or constructing groundwater remediation, recycled water, or desalination facilities or systems to serve existing communities;

enhancing water management by increasing watershed preservation and protection, such as through the use of natural or engineered green infrastructure in the management, conveyance, or treatment of water, wastewater, or stormwater;
enhancing energy efficiency or the use and generation of renewable energy in the management, conveyance, or treatment of water, wastewater, or stormwater;

supporting the adoption and use of advanced water treatment, water supply management (such as reservoir reoperation and water banking), or water demand management technologies, projects, or processes (such as water reuse and recycling, adaptive conservation pricing, and groundwater banking) that maintain or increase water supply or improve water quality;

modifying or replacing existing systems or constructing new systems for existing communities or land currently in agricultural production to improve water supply, reliability, storage, or conveyance in a manner that—
promotes conservation or improves the efficiency of utilization of available water supplies; and
does not further exacerbate stresses on ecosystems or cause redirected impacts by degrading water quality or increasing net greenhouse gas emissions;

supporting practices and projects, such as improved irrigation systems, water banking and other forms of water transactions, groundwater recharge, stormwater capture, groundwater conjunctive use, and reuse or recycling of drainage water, to improve water quality or promote more efficient water use on land currently in agricultural production;
reducing flood damage, risk, and vulnerability by—
restoring floodplains, wetlands, and uplands integral to flood management, protection, prevention, and response;

modifying levees, floodwalls, and other structures through setbacks, notches, gates, removal, or similar means to facilitate reconnection of rivers to floodplains, reduce flood stage height, and reduce damage to properties and populations;
providing for acquisition and easement of flood-prone lands and properties in order to reduce damage to property and risk to populations; or
promoting land use planning that prevents future floodplain development;
conducting and completing studies or assessments to project how changing hydrologic conditions may impact the future operations and sustainability of water systems; or

developing and implementing measures to increase the resilience of water systems and regional and hydrological basins, including the Colorado River Basin, to rapid hydrologic change or a natural disaster (such as tsunami, earthquake, flood, or volcanic eruption).
To seek a grant under this section, the owner or operator of a water system shall submit to the
includes a proposal of the program, strategy, or infrastructure improvement to be planned, designed, constructed, implemented, or maintained by the water system;
cites the best available research or data that demonstrate—

the risk to the water resources or infrastructure of the water system as a result of ongoing or forecasted changes to the hydrological system of a region, including rising sea levels and changes in precipitation patterns; and
how the proposed program, strategy, or infrastructure improvement would perform under the anticipated hydrologic conditions;
explains how the proposed program, strategy, or infrastructure improvement is expected—
to enhance the resiliency of the water system, including source water protection for community water systems, to the anticipated hydrologic conditions; or
to increase efficiency in the use of energy or water of the water system; and
describes how the proposed program, strategy, or infrastructure improvement is consistent with an applicable State, tribe, or local climate adaptation plan, if any.

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Water Infrastructure Resiliency and Sustainability Act of 2013/s:2/ss:h/p:2

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: shall give priority to owners or operators of water systems that are, based on the best available research and data, at the greatest and most immediate risk of facing significant negative impacts due to changing hydrologic conditions.

text.#text: In selecting grantees under this section, subject to

header.#text: Water systems at greatest and most immediate risk

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Water Infrastructure Resiliency and Sustainability Act of 2013/s:2/ss:e/p:1

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: shall ensure that, to the maximum extent practicable, the final list of applications funded for each year includes a substantial number that propose to utilize innovative approaches to meet one or more of the following goals:

text.#text: In selecting among applicants described in
Promoting more efficient water use, water conservation, water reuse, or recycling.
Using decentralized, low-impact development technologies and nonstructural approaches, including practices that use, enhance, or mimic the natural hydrological cycle or protect natural flows.
Reducing stormwater runoff or flooding by protecting or enhancing natural ecosystem functions.
Modifying, upgrading, enhancing, or replacing existing water system infrastructure in response to changing hydrologic conditions.
Improving water quality or quantity for agricultural and municipal uses, including through salinity reduction.
Providing multiple benefits, including to water supply enhancement or demand reduction, water quality protection or improvement, increased flood protection, and ecosystem protection or improvement.

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: to the owner or operator of a water system under
paid through funds distributed under this section shall not exceed 50 percent of the cost of the program, strategy, or infrastructure improvement.
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Water Infrastructure Resiliency and Sustainability Act of 2013/s:2/ss:b

text.#text: The share of the cost of any program, strategy, or infrastructure improvement that is the subject of a grant awarded by the

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Water Infrastructure Resiliency and Sustainability Act of 2013/s:2/ss:d

text.#text: In calculating the non-Federal share of the cost of a program, strategy, or infrastructure improvement proposed by a water system in an application submitted under
include the value of any in-kind services that are integral to the completion of the program, strategy, or infrastructure improvement, including reasonable administrative and overhead costs; and
not include any other amount that the water system involved receives from the Federal Government.

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: a report on progress in implementing this section, including information on project applications received and funded annually.

text.#text: Of the amount made available to carry out this section for a fiscal year, not more than 20 percent may be made available to grantees for activities described in
